instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> How to pair Touch ID to another board
threads.message:
I finally received a donor board for my <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with broken ways on his board. Made one good board out of two, but off course the donorboard has been fixed.
It's not possible anymore to setup Touch ID, although the power on/off feature of that button still works.

Is it possible to pair this touch ID with the new board? If not (as I can guess), is it possible to change the chip with the Touch ID data from the original board to the donorboard? If yes, in which chip is this touch ID data stored?

I possess the touch ID button from that working donor board, but his flatcable has been cut off directly right against the little aluminium shield. So almost not repairable.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> How to pair Touch ID to another board
threads.message: Nobody? At least no one who knows in which chip this Touch ID data is stored?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> How to pair Touch ID to another board
threads.message:
As per schematic, <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> is in charge with Touch ID and Touchbar functions.
Give it a try...
